title: Magic pull away, beat Celtics despite another big Jaylen Brown game: 8 takeaways
author: Tom Westerholm
bullets: The Boston Celtics lost to the Orlando Magic 123-110, despite Jaylen Brown's 32 points on 15-for-28 shooting.
The Celtics struggled with defense, surrendering 38 points in the first quarter and 39 in the fourth.
Payton Pritchard improved his 3-point shooting, finishing 5-for-8 from deep, scoring 27 points for the Celtics.

title: Public reprimand recommended for judge accused of helping immigrant escape ICE
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: Judge Shelley Joseph recommended for public reprimand for creating an appearance of impropriety in a 2018 ICE incident.
Hearing officer found no evidence Joseph was aware of or authorized the defendant's escape from ICE custody.
Federal charges of obstruction against Joseph were dropped in 2022; she now faces criticism but maintains judicial integrity.

title: Alex Cora still high on Red Sox’ future a month after being eliminated by Yankees
author: Kaley Brown
bullets: Red Sox manager Alex Cora remains optimistic about the team's future despite their playoff elimination by the Yankees.
Key roster changes include Trevor Story opting in, Alex Bregman opting out, and Lucas Giolito not receiving a qualifying offer.
Cora highlighted promising performances, especially by rookies like Roman Anthony, as reasons for future optimism.

title: Giant blade breaks off Mass. wind turbine
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: A wind turbine blade detached and fell into a cranberry bog off Head of the Bay Road in Plymouth.
The incident involved a 300-foot turbine; the 75-100 foot blade caused no injuries or public danger.
The turbine automatically entered fail-safe mode; police and maintenance crews are investigating the cause.

title: 5 must-watch movies & TV shows streaming right now
author: Kevin Slane
bullets: 'The Fantastic Four: First Steps' (2025) streams on Disney+, featuring Pedro Pascal and Vanessa Kirby.
'Frankenstein' (2025), directed by Guillermo del Toro, is available on Netflix, starring Jacob Elordi and Oscar Isaac.
'Death by Lightning' is a Netflix limited series about President James A. Garfield, starring Michael Shannon and Matthew Macfadyen.

title: Stefon Diggs reveals what he’s trying to improve about himself after 11 years in the NFL
author: Kaley Brown
bullets: Stefon Diggs aims to improve his attitude, seeking perfection yet understanding the need for self-compassion.
In his first season with the Patriots, Diggs leads in receiving yards (508) and plays a pivotal role in their success.
Diggs credits Patriots coaches for their straightforward guidance, fostering an environment that encourages player growth.

title: Commuter train plows through car on tracks in Acton
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: A commuter train struck an unoccupied car on the tracks in Acton, with no injuries reported.
The incident occurred at 5:30 p.m. at Central Street crossing; the driver's actions are under investigation.
The crash caused delays on the Fitchburg line, and Train 1427 was terminated at South Acton.

title: What to know about possible Red Sox free agent target Munetaka Murakami after posting
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Red Sox could target Munetaka Murakami, a top hitter in Nippon Professional Baseball, as a free agent this offseason.
Murakami, known as the 'Japanese Babe Ruth,' has a career .272 batting average and 142 home runs from 2022-2025.
MLB teams interested in Murakami must pay a posting fee, potentially costing over $16.9 million if his contract exceeds $100 million.

title: Airlines are waiving fees, offering refunds due to reduced flight schedules
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Airlines are waiving fees and offering refunds after the FAA reduced flights by 10% at 40 airports, including Logan.
JetBlue, Southwest, United, American, Delta, and Spirit have policies to assist affected travelers, including waiving change fees.
Massport advises travelers to check with airlines for delays and cancellations due to the ongoing government shutdown.

title: After Cape Cod crash, readers say Mass. should tighten e-bike regulations
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Cape Cod e-bike crash sparks debate on stricter regulations in Massachusetts, following injures to Lynne Forester on a bike trail.
78% of over 580 Boston.com readers support tougher e-bike laws; 20% oppose, citing ineffective regulation over safety.
Massachusetts currently categorizes e-bikes into Classes 1 and 2, with no licensing required; Class 3 remains unregulated.
